intro: Chrysanthemum armenum, commonly known as Armenian chrysanthemum, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus and parts of Turkey. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are usually pale yellow to white, with ray florets that are shorter than the central disk florets. It prefers well-drained soils and full sun, making it a suitable candidate for rock gardens and alpine settings.
